10:34 <bvancea> has joined #medsavant 10:47 <sdumitriu> has joined #medsavant 10:47 <sdumitriu> bvancea, mcupak: Take a look at JPQL 10:55 <mcupak> sdumitriu: what about it? 10:57 <bvancea> hmmm 10:57 <bvancea> looks nice 10:57 <bvancea> we could work on that 10:57 <bvancea> to abstract 10:57 <bvancea> the backend 10:57 <bvancea> the backends* 12:52 <bvancea> sdumitriu: if you could manage to a take a look on what I've committed, I'd like to get some feedback :) 13:05 <sdumitriu1> has joined #medsavant 14:21 <bvancea> oh man, so many blunders :( 14:22 <sdumitriu1> Hehe 14:22 <bvancea> cleaning up stuff now 14:22 <bvancea> btw 14:22 <sdumitriu1> And that was just a quick look 14:22 <bvancea> regarding the code with the wrong licensing 14:22 <bvancea> (yeah, I've found more myself) 14:23 <bvancea> I've took that at the beginning, to get stuff running 14:23 <bvancea> but, as you pointed out, its a different license 14:23 <bvancea> would it be better to just re-write the classes? 14:23 <sdumitriu1> It depends 14:24 <sdumitriu1> In this case you can just reuse it, since it's also our project, we allow you to relicense it 14:24 <sdumitriu1> In general, it depends on how much work that would be for you 14:24 <bvancea> I see 14:25 <sdumitriu1> Sometimes authors will allow you to reuse their code if you ask nicely and explain what you're taking and how it's going to be used 14:25 <sdumitriu1> Most are not OK with relicensing as closed source 14:25 <sdumitriu1> But relicensing for another open source project under another open source license, you have good chances of success as long as it's not a significant amount of code that you're taking 14:26 <sdumitriu1> If it's something too small, you're better of just rewriting it 14:26 <bvancea> I see, thanks for explaning 14:26 <sdumitriu1> If it's something too big, big enough to be a library, you'll probably find another library under a more permissive license 14:26 <bvancea> and sorry for taking it without asking 14:27 <sdumitriu1> Don't worry, you're learning 14:27 <sdumitriu1> That's what GSoC is about 14:27 <bvancea> hmm, I re-reading the MIT and apache licenses 14:27 <sdumitriu1> Learning both how to write code and all the related meta-stuff around coding 14:28 <bvancea> yup :) 14:28 <bvancea> so, the MIT license is more permissive 14:28 <bvancea> than the apache one? 14:28 <sdumitriu1> Yes, that's one of the most permissive ones 14:28 <sdumitriu1> Except the DWTFYW license 14:28 <bvancea> haha 14:29 <bvancea> that's a really funny license 14:29 <bvancea> well, thanks for the feedback 14:29 <sdumitriu1> The most permissive "license" is the public domain 14:29 <sdumitriu1> But that's not really a license 14:29 <bvancea> hmm, how does that work? 14:30 <sdumitriu1> Well, it's stuff that nobody owns 14:30 <bvancea> what kind of software is public domain? 14:30 <sdumitriu1> So you can do anything with it 14:30 <sdumitriu1> Normally stuff becomes public domain when the copyright expires 14:30 <sdumitriu1> Old books are public domain 14:30 <sdumitriu1> Code isn't yet young enough to enter public domain automatically 14:31 <sdumitriu1> So the authors must explicitly declare that they're giving up copyright on something and allow it to be public domain 14:31 <sdumitriu1> But then they can't control in any way what others do with it 14:31 <bvancea> ah, that makes sense 14:32 <bvancea> open source culture is really interesting :D 14:32 <sdumitriu1> (code isn't old enough) 14:32 <bvancea> (yup, noticed) 14:32 <sdumitriu1> The GPL tries to grant the more freedom, but they do that by taking away some permissions 14:33 <sdumitriu1> Like the permission to make something non-free 14:33 <sdumitriu1> That's what makes the GPL family special, and why it's incompatible with most other licenses 14:34 <bvancea> ah, so you can use code licensed under GPL as long as you're doing something purely open-source 14:35 <sdumitriu1> Yes 14:35 <bvancea> but I think you can't modify the actual code under GPL 14:35 <bvancea> just integrate as is 14:35 <sdumitriu1> And GPL is "viral", meaning that the tinyest amount of GPL code makes the whole software GPL 14:35 <bvancea> I remember reading something like this 14:35 <bvancea> oh, I see 14:36 <sdumitriu1> LGPL is more permissive, it affects only the code that is directly touching the GPL code 14:36 <sdumitriu1> So it can be confined in a "library" 14:37 <sdumitriu1> AGPL is even more restrictive, it spreads over the network 14:38 <bvancea> hmmm 14:38 <bvancea> that means that if a software runs on a server offering some servicies 14:38 <bvancea> and I write a second software that uses those services 14:38 <bvancea> my software will be affected? 15:25 <mfiume> has joined #medsavant 15:26 <sdumitriu1> bvancea: Well, not really, it's more about distribution 15:26 <sdumitriu1> Some smart guys found a loophole in the GPL license 15:26 <sdumitriu1> It requires you to distribute the sources any time you distribute the software 15:27 <sdumitriu1> But since accessing the software through network isn't actual "distribution", the GPL doesn't really apply 15:27 <bvancea> oh, I see 15:27 <bvancea> clever 15:27 <sdumitriu1> Although the GPL was defined before the internet became popular, so distributing software was the only way to use it 15:28 <sdumitriu1> So what they actually meant is "let the user use the software", not "distribute the software to the user so that he can use it" 15:28 <sdumitriu1> AGPL corrected this language to make it clear that any kind of usage counts 15:29 <bvancea> I see 15:29 <bvancea> it makes sense 15:29 <sdumitriu1> Going back to the network usage, it depend 15:30 <sdumitriu1> s 15:30 <sdumitriu1> For example, the way PhenoTips is packaged to include Solr as a web application used through SolrJ, it's communication over the network 15:30 <sdumitriu1> But Solr is a key element of the whole package 15:31 <sdumitriu1> So the AGPL should apply to the rest of PhenoTips if Solr was under the AGPL and PhenoTips wasn't 15:31 <bvancea> hehe, nice 15:31 <sdumitriu1> But if you're offering a public Solr server that anybody can connect to, and someone connects to it with a non-AGPL client, then it shouldn't be bound to the AGPL, since it's an external user 15:33 <bvancea> I see, that is true if Solr would be licensed under the AGPL 15:33 <sdumitriu1> Yes 15:33 <sdumitriu1> But fortunately it's under Apache 15:33 <sdumitriu1> So you can use it in any way 15:34 <bvancea> yup 15:34 <bvancea> so, If I may ask 15:34 <sdumitriu1> A difference between GPL2 and GPL3 15:34 <sdumitriu1> TIVO-ization 15:34 <bvancea> how did you decide on the licesing for the lab software? (keep going on your idea though, and answer this later) 15:35 <sdumitriu1> Basically, hardware makers found another loophole in the GPL 15:35 <sdumitriu1> They put software on their hardware, they do give the sources to the software, but they don't allow you to change in any way what's already on the hardware 15:36 <sdumitriu1> So as a user, you have the sources, you can't modify them, but you can't put the modified software on the machine 15:36 <sdumitriu1> So it's completely useless 15:36 <sdumitriu1> You don't really have the freedom to improve your device 15:36 <sdumitriu1> And that's one of the freedoms that GPL enforces 15:37 <sdumitriu1> GPL3 prevents that as well 15:37 <sdumitriu1> Choosing... 15:38 <sdumitriu1> Well, I'm not sure why the Apache one was chosen for Savant and MedSavant 15:38 <sdumitriu1> Probably because it's becoming the most popular open source license 15:39 <sdumitriu1> Basically people are split into two licensing camps, the GPL and the rest 15:39 <sdumitriu1> And it goes down to the difference between "free software (free as in freedom, not as in beer)", and "open source" 15:40 <sdumitriu1> One is emphasizing the freedom of the users, the other is trying to get the best code 15:40 <bvancea> oh, I see 15:40 <sdumitriu1> So free software is about ensuring that users have the freedom to improve their software 15:41 <sdumitriu1> Open source is about applying development practices that make good software 15:41 <sdumitriu1> GPL doesn't let others take away these freedoms 15:42 <sdumitriu1> The other licenses do let companies use the code in non-open ways, but they encourage participation 15:42 <sdumitriu1> On the non-GPL side, the most popular ones are Apache, MIT/BSD, Mozilla, Eclipse 15:43 <sdumitriu1> MIT/BSD keep things simple 15:43 <sdumitriu1> Mozilla and Eclipse are mostly used in their ecosystems 15:44 <bvancea> I didn't hear about Mozilla and Eclipse before 15:44 <sdumitriu1> So Apache is usually the obvious choice 15:44 <sdumitriu1> MPL/EPL 15:44 <sdumitriu1> They all look a lot like Apache 15:44 <sdumitriu1> The language is a bit different 15:45 <sdumitriu1> The weird thing about the MPL is that it puts restrictions on the naming of derivatives 15:45 <sdumitriu1> Basically, only official Firefox builds are allowed to be called Firefox 15:46 <sdumitriu1> That's why Debian has IceWeasel and not Firefox, since they patch the sources they're not allowed to call it Firefox 15:47 <bvancea> haha 15:47 <bvancea> I was always wondering about iceweasel 15:47 <sdumitriu1> That's for protecting the name, as a legal defence against buggy derivates that could harm the Firefox brand 15:47 <bvancea> make sense 15:48 <bvancea> makes* 15:48 <sdumitriu1> Since I'm on the Free Software side, I chose the most permissive GPL license, the LGPL 15:49 <sdumitriu1> Well, kind of, it actually got grandfathered from XWiki anyway 15:50 <bvancea> the LGPL? 15:50 <sdumitriu1> Yes 15:51 <bvancea> cool 15:52 <bvancea> what's the story behind that? 15:53 <sdumitriu1> Since XWiki was started by a company, the original author wanted to protect his business, so he chose the license that is best for that: GPL 15:53 <sdumitriu1> A few months later switched to LGPL, which is more permissive for users, and less scary for companies 15:55 <bvancea> I see 15:55 <sdumitriu1> When I got to XWiki I was also mostly using the LGPL for my other projects 15:59 <bvancea> nice, thanks for the explanation 15:59 <bvancea> :D 16:00 <bvancea> so apparently the GPL family is the way to go if you start a project and want to protect your rights 16:01 <sdumitriu1> Yes 16:01 <sdumitriu1> Apache is better if you want more contributos 16:01 <sdumitriu1> contributors 16:02 <sdumitriu1> Although the Linux kernel contradicts that, it has more contributors than any Apache project 16:02 <sdumitriu1> Probably more than *any* project, actually 16:03 <bvancea> hehe, didn't think about that before 16:03 <bvancea> apache has a lot of project though 16:03 <sdumitriu1> Yes 16:03 <sdumitriu1> Most are small scale, though 16:04 <bvancea> yup 16:04 <bvancea> I think Hadoop and Cassandra have the most contributers 16:06
